title: Friday, 11th January 2019

A FTSE 250 packaging company formed from acquisitions with some questions hanging over it with regards core value and cash generation. Stop me if you've heard this one before.

UDG Healthcare PLC (UDG:LSE): Last: 584.00, down 42.5 (-6.78%), High: 607.50, Low: 573.00, Volume: 644.88k
11:21 am
BE11:22am

2H recovery in Sharp US was overshadowed by challenges at Ashfield C&C and disappointing perf from M&A, evident by $11.6m deferred consideration release on prior deals. 2/3 of the business now seems to be facing pressures with the only immediate relief likely from potential M&A which at 0.35x leverage management is very keen on. For 2019, we forecast c.5% Adj. EPS growth ex deals but inclusive of investments. Downgrade to Hold; 620p PT.

red @Excel Developernowotny on wires saying german q4 will be slower but says still in positive territory. dont like odds for other eu members tho
BE11:22am

Sharp is the blister-pill packaging bit and Ashfield is the contract sales and marketing bit, if I remember correctly.

FATDAZ @red but Q3 was negative GDP was -0.2% so that doesn't stack up
wayneJ @Dec69 - possibly but on a £6.7m market cap co. - it is a Hotel California stock - u can always get in but you can never leave
VV75 anything on Intercontinental Hotel Group? Somewhere is a report touting it's takeover appeal I've heard.
BE11:23am

We believe U/L profit growth will be constrained by UDG’s “STEM aXcellerate” cost savings initiative. Furthermore, with C&C below JEFe in 2018 and with recent deals missing expectations, we are now more cautious on the recovery and sustainability of recent u/l growth.

red @chad_johnpenny share pump and dump. second oldest profession
FATDAZ @VV75 IHG were written up yesterday I think
11:23 am
BE11:24am

And, well, it's a rollup.

BE11:24am

Value accretive M&A is central to UDG's growth strategy; In FY18 UDG executed 2 deals; we expect UDG could lever up to 2.5x, giving c.$400-500mn of firepower, though we note with UDG releasing deferred consideration from 3 recent deals the mkt is ascribing a higher discount to M&A than in the past; with a potential rate rise environment we believe investors are less bullish on roll-ups.

red @FATDAZcompanies currently reporting their second half 2018/q4 2018, that are doing business in germany (in particular construction manufacturing side) have shown weak end to 2018. that doesn't bode well as you say.
BE11:24am

You've also got results due Jan 29.

11:24 am
BE11:25am

While formal FY19 guidance is expected on Jan 29, UDG's preliminary expectation is for continuation of 2018 trends; at 2% EPS growth from u/l trading in 2018, that does not sound attractive to us. With planned investments and pressure in Ashfield we forecast US$48c (4.5% growth). UDG is therefore likely to use its c. $400-500m M&A firepower to sweeten the proposition. While 2018 included an impact from Future Fit cost savings program, 2019 is similarly going to be weighed on by STEM aXcellerate costs, mostly on personnel.

BE11:25am

So that's that.

undefined

BE11:30am

You also had a UBS upgrade yesterday though that was just valuation.

BE11:30am

Previously we valued IHG on 12.5x 2018e EV/ EBITDAR but we roll forward to 2019 forecasts. Nevertheless, as we are one year further into the cycle, we reduce the valuation multiple from 12.5x to 12.0x (on peak earnings the multiple was c8x EV/EBITDAR in the last cycle) and, coupled with the change to forecasts, our new PT is £42.75 (previously £40). We now rate the shares Neutral (from Sell) with our only Buy rated European hotel share Accor.

FATDAZ @Red no doubt

The current broader market for air travel remains challenging for all parties. There have been a number of airlines who have gone out of business over the past year. While Flybe has made tangible progress in delivering its strategy, maintaining momentum has been hampered by the challenging market environment: Ongoing fuel and currency impacts have presented particularly significant headwinds for Flybe as has the rapid and significant tightening on Flybe's liquidity from the card acquirer market. In addition, the general economic outlook and conditions have impacted the business recently leading to a further weakening in consumer demand, affecting cash, revenues and profit adversely.

red @Flaneurlikely would only grant it if referendum propsed. otherwise the WA has been agreed and no reason for UK not to ratify it, otherwise no deal.
BE11:33am

The Flybe Directors have taken into careful consideration the risks inherent to the successful execution of Flybe's business plan given these developing factors versus the opportunity that a cash bid and the offer of funding for the business provides. Such risks include further softening in demand in the short-haul market, potential for further cash flow challenges in the short-term, weather events and further adverse movements in fuel prices, sterling and customer sentiment.

BE11:44am

Pointing out the negative impact of Brexit on the pound is an easy endeavour. It’s why it trades as poorly as it does. The more difficult task has been to take the other side and compare the market pricing to how bad things will be once Brexit happens (hard or soft) and point out market mispricing. We have held our short EUR/GBP trade for over a week now. It’s gone pretty much nowhere. That’s a concern because of the moves we by MPs,
which have reduced the risk of a hard Brexit even further in our view.
The lessons learnt from UK politics and the pound over the past few years is that the price action over the next week will likely contain a lot of gap risk, probably lack a clear direction, and see the market jump quickly on negative news, but equally see short positions disappointed by politicians finding a way to fudge things through. Both sides of the trade tend to get frustrated and range-bound price action continues.
Despite our view that the GBP market is mispriced and should eventually trade higher we want to be tactical in our approach and reduce our risk over the event. We exit for a small profit at 0.9000 and wait for some Brexit clarity as to what happens next and will review GBP longs when we get a better idea of where things are heading next.

Shinshin If there is an A50 extension/cancellation, and UK takes part in the 2019 EU elections, that will be....lively.
red @Dec69 - Skepticagree. i would/will be going long certain uk assets on a no deal if we are around parity/1.05 on eurgbp. i would be prepared to sit thru worse levels but would expect a return within 3-5 years. however going on history and also how mkts love to do things quickly these days, it could be 6 mnths.
FATDAZ @waynej glad to see that I am not the only one of that opinion re Grayling
Dec69 - Skeptic I'm waiting for a paper to run how Brexit killed the Car Industry. Yes, cycles in the car industry, forget this, lets just blame a Brexit.

So, down first.

Excel Developer Grayling is just rubbish, encore
11:45 am
BE11:45am

 Theresa May is likely to lose the vote next week; the expected vote split is in the region of 423 against. Despite being fully expected, clients still expect GBP to suffer initially. We can see the market selling GBP slightly on the confirmation of the vote loss, but wouldn’t focus too much on that, it’s about what’s next.
 The Labour Party may look to table a vote of no confidence in the
government. This would lead to 12-24 hours of waiting for that vote to take place, plenty of time for the market to focus on the tail risk of a new election.
GBP should suffer while we wait for that vote to take place. The good news is that Labour has not followed through on its suggestion of a confidence vote thus far and even if it does follow through, we do not expect it to pass.

BE11:45am

Then up later.

Forester I can see the both Parliament and the EU agreeing to a SHORT delay given where we are now, to allow for a few weeks of (attempted) renegotiations when TM's deal voted down. A few months aint gonna make much difference in the overall scheme of things
wayneJ It seems to me that IHG and Dominos Pizza are the same - get the franchisees to stump up the cash, demand increasing investment and franchise fees every year; tell the City you have great ROIC and then hush up when the franchisees despair....
BE11:46am

 After the vote fails Theresa May could give a statement outside No.10 to explain what she plans to do next. This could hint at her Plan B in its aftermath such as a customs union (the Labour party’s Brexit policy) and more. GBP
could benefit from that as it would be difficult for parliament to reject it.
 MPs could force the government to adopt a softer Brexit stance: Plan B for Brexit is amendable and MPs could decide part of the Brexit policy for the government. Parliamentary procedure is currently being re-written by the actions of the speaker this week, but the government expects only one
amendment to be allowed by MPs on that Plan B vote if and when it comes (expected on 21 Jan). Given how important this is, we’d take that with a pinch of salt and expect MPs to try and find a consensus as to the next course of action in the Brexit talks.
 An extension of Article 50 could become confirmed, the market would take a long extension well as it would allow room for a possible referendum. A short extension would not be so positive as it simply kicks the can a month or so down the road and the cliff edge/procrastination risk remains.

PBateman Morning all, sorry I am late

BE11:57am

The group has struggled to meet Wipac customer demand and has continued to incur additional costs in H2; including manufacturing inefficiencies, expedited freight costs and consultant fees. The poor customer service levels has also had a knock-on impact on the awarding of new programmes anticipated in H2, and profit recognition thereon. Although progress has been achieved in the past month to reduce the customer backlog and the additional costs are expected to gradually decline over the coming months, LED Technologies profit for the full year is now expected to be significantly below the Board’s previous expectations.

BE11:57am

Technical Plastics has made solid progress in the second half as the operational improvement programme has been successfully implemented, albeit at a slower rate than anticipated. As a result, FY operating profit for this Division is now expected to be broadly similar to the prior year with the second half much improved over the first. The Aerospace division continues to perform slightly ahead of expectations.

BE11:57am

The Board now expects the Group results for the full year to be significantly below its previous expectations, with the second half performance anticipated to be similar to that achieved in the first half. We have cut our Mar’19 PBT by 33% to £7.0m and recognise that a number of project milestones and new programme awards are required in the final quarter. It also assumes that any one-off costs associated with reorganising the Wipac operation and rectifying its performance are treated as exceptional costs. We have cut our Mar’20 PBT by 38% to £7.5m. We feel it is prudent at this stage to assume no overall improvement Wipac profits next year but anticipate continued growth in Technical Plastics and a stable performance in Aerospace.

BE12:06pm

 We believe Saudi and UAE are fundamentally different markets.
Saudi has higher reliance on government pay; longer payment days and
higher write-offs; a declining expat population as well as local competition
from established players. We therefore think the Saudi journey is unlikely to
be a smooth one.
 Outside of Saudi, NMC’s strategy is increasingly broad: Post 18
deals in 12m we believe it is more difficult to anticipate NMC’s future
direction and evaluate individual deals. Despite numerous M&A
transactions contributing to 100+ facilities in 17 countries, we estimate 62%
of NMC’s EBITDA comes from 6 facilities.
 Elsewhere, concerns exist over cash and governance: NMC’s cash
conversion post interest and tangible capex is c. 25% which in our view
places increasing reliance on outside capital for future growth. While recent
feedback around remuneration has gotten a response, neither cash
conversion nor ROIC are part of management incentives plans.
